sub_title: Office for Risk Assessment & Research, Nederlandse Voedsel- en Warenautoriteit (NVWA)
summary:
For nearly 25 years I work in the field of consumer protection. Non-food product safety is a broad and interesting field of work. It includes toys, child care articles, chemical products, biocides, textiles and cosmetics. There is a lot of developement in legislation, new products, new hazards.

I have worked for more than 10 years as project leader and specialist in various areas (food contact materials, toys, chemical substances and mixture). I have been involved in standardisation work, also as convenor. Also I have worked in EU working groups, for example on active and intelligent packaging. More recently as working group leader in a joint action EU-China on toys.

The last 5 years I worked as manager of the non-food laboratory (chemical/microbiological). This laboratory deals with the full range of non-food products. The product safety laboratory works according to a strict quality system. Enforcement of legislation is a very important task and therefore all results must be reliable. Another task is to develop new analytical methods for new legal requirements or for new products. Investigation of consumer complaints is a relevant task as well, as a service to consumers, but also to detect non-compliant products.

In March 2019 I started with a new challenge, as a Coordinating/specialist advisor product safety at the Office of Risk Assessment. My job is to look at the chemical risks that are related to consumer products.

publications.name: Migration of formaldehyde from ‘biobased’ bamboo/melamine cups: A Dutch retail survey

profile_positions.description:
The SEPAWA Benelux is part of the Germany created SEPAWA association. The history of the association goes back to 1800. Since the fifties of the last century, with the advent of modern detergents, it was necessary to reform the society and to all new technologies which were introduced in the sector. From the soap boiler association, the SEPAWA was born in 1954 in Ludwigshafen. The SEPAWA has grown in the last fifty years. With more than 1200 members, the SEPAWA is one of the largest specialized trade unions in Europe. 

The Netherlands Sepawa Section was founded in Amersfoort in 1997. It was the first president Raymond Vredevoort who took the initiative. A few years later, the association turned to the Sepawa Benelux. Since its inception the Sepawa Benelux became the platform for people who directly or indirectly involved in the detergents, cosmetics and perfume industry. This may be seen in the broadest sense. Public services or interest groups may be interested and are also often present at the activities.

The Sepawa Benelux organize twice a year, a number of lectures. These lectures may be scientific in nature but also often explain the ever changing legal framework of our sector. Marketing issues are also often the bid.
profile_positions.title: Secretary Sepawa Benelux

profile_positions.description:
The product safety laboratory in Groningen carries out chemical and microbiological tests. Product safety comprises a broad field, such as toys, child care articles, textiles, biocides, chemicals, cosmetics. The laboratory works according to a strict quality system. For enforcement it is necessarry to have reliable results. Part of the work is enforcement of legal limits. Another important task is to develop methods for new legislation or new products.

The laboratory works in close cooperation with the inspectors.

CHEK is a special unit within this laboratory. CHEK has specialised in quality assurance for laboratory research: chemical, microbiological and physical/electro technical analysis in food and non-food products. CHEK organises, distributes and reports of proficiency studies and also produces reference materials.
profile_positions.title: Laboratory Manager

profile_positions.description:
The aim of Joint Action 2 is to establish seamless surveillance for toys imported from China to the EU. The Chinese governement performs export control of toys that are exported to the EU, to ensure compliance with EU legislation. When the check by the Chinese government is correct, the control in the EU can be reduced. This will enable EU authorities to focus on companies that are not in the Chinese export system. 3 working groups with participants from both Chinese and EU side were formed for the practical implementation of this Joint Action.

The aim of this working group is to provide a risk based test scheme to ensure the safety of toys, imported from China to the EU. The Toy safety directive sets requirements for the chemical and physical-mechanical safety, the hygiene and also flammability of toys. Some of the requirements are covered by (harmonised) standards, some of the requirements are open.

This working group is preparing a risk-based tool to select the proper tests for toys, to ensure the safety of the toy, but to avoid unnecessary testing.

This working group works in close cooperation with the 2 other working groups:
- laboratory comparison tests 
- data exchange
profile_positions.title: Chairman working group Joint Action China 2

profile_positions.description:
The taskgroup CEN TC 252/WG 5/TG 2 'certain elements' is part of the working group on chemical safety of toys. The laboratory of the NVWA was selected as lead laboratory to revise standard EN71-3 (safety of toys - migration of certain elements). In 2009 a new Toy Safety Directive was published (directive 2009/48/EC), setting new migration limits for certain elements. The existing list of elements was expanded and 2 special elements were introduced: speciation of Chromium (III and VI), and organic tin. Also 3 categories of toy materials were introduced: powder/brittle, liquid and scraped-off. These new chemical requirements came into force in July 2013.

The NVWA laboratory developed analytical methods for these new requirements. These methods were validated by both the NVWA laboratory and the peer review laboratory (ICQ). Reference materials were developed for all elements and all material categories. In 2011 the NVWA laboratory organised a round robin with these reference materials. The task group revised the standard EN71-3 to meet the requirements set in the directive, now including the 3 new analytical methods. In the Formal Vote round 100% of positive votes were recieved. In 2013 this new standard was published in the Official Journal.
profile_positions.title: Convenor standardisation task group 'migration of certain elements'

profile_positions.description:
Specialisation of chemical safety of childcare articles and toys and household chemicals.
The main tasks are: expertise centre, coordination of enforcement, advising policy making authorities, training of inspectors, informing consumers and industry, participation in national and international normalisation committees, participation in EU projects.

Replacement of  the head our department, responsible for the national year plan and realisation for chemical product safety.
profile_positions.title: Public Health Officer

profile_positions.description:
Research trainee at the Twente University. Study of the synthesis, degradation, crystallisation behaviour, structure and mechanical properties of polyesteramides. This Ph D project was sponsored by GE Plastics. Supervision of practical work for second- and third-year students and of thesis work of 5 master students.

Thesis is titled ‘Polyesteramides based on PET and nylon 2,T’. The work was supervised by dr. Gaymans and prof. Feijen.

March 1998 Course ‘Thermoplastic Elastomers’
May 1995 Course ’Mechanical properties of polymers’
These are three-day courses given at the Twente University
profile_positions.title: Ph.D. student Polymer Engineering

volunteer_experiences.description:
Het coordineren en organiseren van activiteiten voor de kinderen. De belangrijkste activiteiten zijn Sinterklaas, kerst, creatieve middagen, avondwandelvierdaagse, en natuurlijk een spetterend eindfeest. Met zijn allen (ouders, leerlingen en leerkrachten) maken we het gezellig op school!

Zie ook: https://www.dewesterburcht.nl/pagina/263915/Oudervereniging

De oudervereniging organiseert allerlei evenementen op school, waaronder Sinterklaas, Kerst, carnaval, avondvierdaagse, schoolreisje. Samen met de leerkrachten willen we voor de leerlingen zorgen voor sfeer en gezelligheid.

Zie ook www.mariaschool-paterswolde.nl

Zie ook www.speelotheekeelde.nl

De Speelotheek in Eelde bevindt zich achter in de bibliotheek. Deze wordt gerund door vrijwilligers. Leden (kinderen) kunnen hier speelgoed en spellen lenen. Het voordeel van de Speelotheek is dat je op een gemakkelijke manier van alles kunt uitproberen en bijvoorbeeld ook eens iets meenemen dat groot is, zoals een glijbaan, maar geen blijvende plek inneemt.
Een ander voordeel is dat je goed kunt blijven inspelen op de veranderende belangstelling van een kind. Als je kind nog maar net kan lopen kun je bij ons een giraf lenen, waarop het kan fietsen. Is het iets ouder, dan hebben we een loopfiets. En voor daarna verschillende steps en ander speelgoed. We groeien met je kind mee.
De Speelotheek Eelde heeft een uitgebreide collectie speelgoed, van diverse categorien. Het is kwalitatief hoogwaardig speelgoed.

Daarnaast organiseert de Speelotheek Eelde 2 keer per jaar een kledingbeurs. Hier wordt tweedehands kleding en speelgoed verkocht. De beurs is laagdrempelig en gemoedelijk van karakter.
